did.head: Papers Summary
did.abstract: The John Merriman McGhee papers contain four handwritten and typed transcripts of letters McGhee wrote home as part of the 16th Alabama Infantry during the American Civil War.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: John Merriman McGhee (1838-1902) was born in Lawrence County, Alabama. At some point, he married Margaret Malvinas Wear McGhee; it is unknown if they had any children. At the start of the American Civil War, he enlisted in Company F, 16th Alabama Infantry, as a first lieutenant. As a member of the 16th Alabama Infantry during the entire war, he would have participated in the battles of Shiloh, Chickamauga, and Franklin, among others, as part of the Confederate Army of Tennessee. Sometime after the war, he moved to Brownwood, Texas. McGhee passed away on 1902 March 24 and was buried in Oakwood Cemetery, Waco, Texas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The John Merriman McGhee papers contain four handwritten and typed transcripts of Civil War-era letters, arranged in one series: I. Correspondence. These letters primarily describe life in Confederate army camps. Some battle descriptions are included. McGhee also discusses General Thomas J. "Stonewall" Jackson's death, dread about Vicksburg possibly falling to the United States army, and other events.
This collection was originally named the J.M. McGhee papers. As part of the research for this finding aid, more information was found, and it was renamed the John Merriman McGhee papers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The John Merriman McGhee papers were arranged in one folder prior to current processing. Previous arrangement was retained.
Currently, the John Merriman McGhee papers are arranged in one series: I. Correspondence.
